The former town Karis in Finland ("Karjaa" in Finnish) is equally controversial. It's split between a long A and a short A when talking about the Swedish name (which is Karis). The long A is what The Institute for the Languages of Finland recommends using while the short A is used in the local dialect of Karis. Interestingly, a majority prefers using the short A while I use the long A.

For me, it‚Äôs like ‚Äúgift‚Äù because‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs like ‚Äúgift.‚Äù English seems to agree that if you want a voiced velar plosive sound before the vowel and a labiodental fricative after, you use G (gift, give, goof, golf, gulf, grief, graph) and if you want an affricate in that situation, you use J (jiff, Jeff, jive, Jove).

I feel like all the acronyms listed to disapprove the acronym argument all have issues that make them irrelevant.   JPEG has the issue of being a mix between an initialism AND an acronym. The J is spoken but the ‚ÄúPEG‚Äù is pronounced. Dunno how that‚Äôs ever used as an argument, no one is arguing to call it ‚ÄúG-IF‚Äù.  Laser has a long vowel sound. It has a vowel-consonant-E spelling which means emphasis is given to the A and will require the L to be pronounced in a specific way to ensure emphasis can be given to the A.   Scuba‚Ä¶ I- idk how he came to the pronunciation for scuba. Because he pronounced ‚Äúlaser‚Äù how it would be if the pronouncing of the original words was taken into account but the way he pronounced scuba is nothing like how the original words sound. I think what he meant was that‚Äôs how scuba would be pronounced if it was pronounced according to its SPELLING. That‚Äôs a fair point but a lot of English words for some reason aren‚Äôt pronounced how they‚Äôre spelt so I think scuba is just a complete outlier.  GIF can‚Äôt be compared to acronyms like Laser or JPEG because it doesn‚Äôt have the vowel-con-E spelling of laser that need to be emphasised or the wacky initialism-acronym combo of JPEG.  I feel like the most telling evidence of how the word should be pronounced is in the word ‚Äúgift‚Äù. The closest possible word to ‚ÄúGIF‚Äù. It‚Äôs not a name (proper noun, whatever you wanna call it), doesn‚Äôt have any extra vowels, only has one extra consonant, spelt identically (excluding the T obviously).  But all of this doesn‚Äôt matter because language isn‚Äôt bound by strict rules like this. All that matters is that you can convey an idea to another person effectively and efficiently which is why both pronunciations are accepted (although one will make you look weird).

Ultimately, what I think it comes down to is that there's no inherent reason it has to be either.  I think soft g has a slightly stronger claim to having a 'right' to be pronounced that way, hard g 'looks' slightly more like how a word would be pronounced, but ultimately, people will say the word how they feel like saying it.  Which is...  Listen.  Say it how you like, but by no means pretend that you have the inherently 'correct' choice.  You have *a* choice.  Nothing more, nothing less.

It's jif, like the peanut butter. You don't use the same logic for pronouncing the letter in a lot of other acronyms (JPEG isn't JFEG despite the P standing for photographic). Then there's other examples like laser, where you'd have to pronounce it Lah-zer, or scuba being pronounced scubbuh (the A in laser stands for amplification, and the u in scuba stands for underwater). JIF is a familiar brand of peanut butter (in the US) and JIFF is an actual familiar word, so upon seeing GIF it seems only natural to assume it is spelled that way to make sure you don't accidentally pronounce it like JIF or JIFF.
The most important purpose is to be understood. Pronouncing as in Gift maximises the chances of someone hearing GIF and never JIF. Patterns observed for other words or the inventors opinion should regarded as interesting but secondary to the purpose of language.

If you were using PCs in the mid 1980s like me, there was no debate.  They were "jif" files.  It wasn't until the modern internet and memeing in the 2000s that a broad swathe of the population suddenly heard of this file format, and began mispronouncing it.  And now the wrong pronunciation has become the most popular.

It's about knowledge, those who know that GIF stands for "graphics interchange format" will use [gif] (same [g] as in graphics), those who don't know will use [d3] (in English as in many European languages, [g], [c] before [e], [i], [y] usually changes its pronunciation).

It'll be nice when linguists finally stop wrongfully dry humping descriptivism to death. The only reason you're able to make any sense of new utterances is because of preexisting, _prescriptive_ aspects of language that alone are responsible for communication taking place rather than something being little more than an exchange of drawings, noises, and facial/body movements. Not only that, once a new anything is incorporated into a language, it inherently becomes prescriptive. Or by all means, be bitches because crazy, right?

There's a rule for acronyms: every letter ending up in the acronym is pronounced the same as the letter in the word being shortened.  So it doesn't matter what anyone thinks or wants. If the G is short for Graphics in the acronym GIF, then it's pronounced GIF and not JIF. No one says jraphics.

It seems that all instance of ‚Äúg‚Äù sounding like ‚Äúj‚Äù come from words that are derived from Latin. Whereas all instances of a hard ‚Äúg‚Äù are from German. To prove my point further the reason we pronounce German with a soft ‚Äúg‚Äù or ‚Äúj‚Äù sound is because it comes from Latin. As English is still considered a largely Germanic language I feel we should consider those roots when deciding on pronunciation. Germanic pronunciation would be to pronounce GIF with a hard ‚Äúg‚Äù. When further consider that ‚ÄúGraphics‚Äù comes from the Greek ‚ÄúGraphikos‚Äù it would be foolish to apply any Latin pronunciation to it. Neither the root of the word nor the language in which it‚Äôs acronym were created are Latin based, so a soft ‚Äúg‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make sense.

If you put any stock in the debate about "other words that start with gi," then just make sure you that follow that logic the REST of the way, and add the next letter ("f"). There's actually only ONE word in English that starts with "gif," and yep... it's "gift" (and its variations, such as "gifted"). So, if you're going to say that we should look to other words to set the precedent for us, just know that you've already pigeonholed yourself into pronouncing it the only correct way (like "gift").

My argument why it's pronounced "gif" not "jif": There is an image extension called ".jiff", so to avoid confusion we should pronounce gif and not jif, otherwise when speaking it would only cause confusion. I think different languages also influence the pronunciation. For example, in Italian words with the soft "g" are more common than the harder "g". Yet in Spanish, there isn't a word with soft "g", words with g are always either a hard "g" or an even harder "g" (the "h" sound in hammer for example). So in Spanish is Gif.

†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†·Ö†· Creators of a word can only describe how **they** pronounce the word.  They have no ability to say what the "correct" pronunciation of it is, because pronunciation of words is a social construct.    If the creator of a word got to decide how it was pronounced, do you know how we'd be pronouncing the word "between" today?  Betweox.  And that's only if the guy who made the Latin word "inter" doesn't pipe up!

This entire debate is just native English speakers coming frustratingly close to the realisation that their language has subpar, inconsistent orthography.  Not to hate on English, it's got its upsides, but you cannot "read" English. You learn letter sequences by heart that you've accepted mean a word with little in the way of system or consistency throughout the language as a whole.  But this also won't change.

Jif is peanut butter and gif is the right word
Anyone that pronounces it with a hard G is not an old school computer person. Back in the day, all files were pronounced by their three letters (A.V.I., J.P.G., G.I.F., M.P.G....etc). Now, start saying G.I.F. letters over and over and faster, it evolves to the pronunciation JIF. Which is what happened back in the day when people were constantly referring to the G.I.F. file it eventually became JIF.   Now fast forward later when every started getting computers and seeing reference to a file with extension .GIF, without having the old school background or knowledge, they just say GIF with a hard G. It became a way to distinguish if someone knew their computer SH*T vs those who didn't at the time by the way they pronounced it.
Jif is a peanut butter...I'm calling Gif not peanut butter...
I guess the only way this problem will be solved is when a new format that supports animated graphics finally replaces GIF, I mean the format was released in 1987 and one of it functions was to present lossless images, a task PNG already took from it, in fact several animated image formats already exist and are way more efficient, the only thing holding them back is lack of universal adoption and support.

It's definitely pronounced with a hard G, because the most similar words to gif are gist and gift, but gist comes from french and gift from middle English and old Norse, thus it's closer to English root. Since gif isn't a borrowed word from french, there's absolutely no reason to call it jif.

The "jif" pronunciation will always be my preferred one, because it is consistent with Latin's influence on English. In the Latin language I know best, "ci" and "gi" are always pronounced the soft way. If you want to get a hard sound, you have to put in an interrupting "h" ("chi" and "ghi"). I know English isn't a fan, but I enjoy language better when there are consistent rules for pronunciation.

We dont have that problem in spanish. The G pronounciation depends on wether its followed by either A, O and U (like garden), E and I (in that case we pronounce it like an h: hell or him), ue or ui (like gift or guess) and √ºe or √ºi (in this case the u is not silent). The pronounciation follows strict rules that are clear.

Gif is pronounced yiff  Fun fact, the source of this debate comes from English borrowed words. You see, while words borrowed from Old Norse kept their hard Gs, words from Old French had a sound shift where the G would soften in front of front vowels (ee, e, and i). Interestingly, Old English words with G underwent a sound shift where the Gs became Ys, so, since GIF is an English-made word, the correct pronunciation is "yiff"

Ah, I was always wondering how to pronounce gif, glad I finally know that it's pronounced gif
I've never understood why descriptivism is considered in such high regard these days. The written language exists to store ideas in a permanent format, so that information isn't lost in memory and verbal retellings. It's also to give people a structure that they can use to learn the language itself. Descriptivism is counterintuitive to both of these things. No, we _don't_ simply use the language to describe how people speak. People speak _using_ the language. And yes, language changes, in the sense that new concepts arise and need new words. No, it should not be considered a valid "change" in language if people start using the wrong spelling or pronunciation en masse. The original usage was usually that way for a reason, and accepting people being wrong as suddenly being right muddles and obscures that reason.   Take the word "mischievous" for example. It comes from "mischief". The correct pronunciation is "mischief", but replace the "f" with "vous" (sounding like vuss). You can tell that mischievous comes from mischief just by hearing it, and therefore get a sense of its meaning, even if you've never heard it before. However, it has become more and more common to pronounce mischievous as "miss-chee-vee-uss", which is just...horribly wrong. There's no excuse for pronouncing it that way. And yet, it has started to become an officially "accepted" pronunciation of the word, because people are wrong so often. But you can't tell what the word means when it's mispronounced, because it sounds nothing like its root word. Thus, we have lost intuitive and clear meaning because of descriptivism.   Now, obviously not every word that gets spelled or pronounced incorrectly will have the exact problems given in this example. My point was simply that words usually have meaning that can be inferred without necessarily having heard that exact word before, and descriptivism is a surefire way to destroy that clarity.   And yes, I've heard the "but language changes all the time, look at these words that meant something totally different hundreds of years ago" argument. And it's complete nonsense. Simply because something has been wrong for so long doesn't make it right to continue in that manner. Should we have kept slaves around, simply because we'd already been doing it for a long time? Education is more easily available now than ever before. There's no reason people shouldn't be held accountable to using the correct forms of the words they're using. And I'm not arguing that we should go back to the original meanings/spellings/pronunciations of words that have already changed due to descriptivism. That would take an unreasonable amount of effort and be doomed to fail. However, we _can_ stop the degradation of our language, and our understanding of our language, if we actually care to do so. Sadly, it seems most people "in charge" of such things (i.e., linguists) don't care

Personally I use a hard g, because Gift uses one. I understand that linguistically they aren't related, but it feels as if the addition of a voiceless alveolar stop (shout out jan Misali and Conlang Critic) at the end shouldn't have an effect on the g, in the same way that adding ed to gift doesn't change the pronunciation of gifted.   Also, from my limited google research, it appears that many of the words that begin with Gi that have a soft g are derived from older iterations of Romance languages, and Gi with a hard g seems to be more indicative of Germanic languages. Although I'm sure this is not an exact rule, it vaguely looks like a pattern is forming.  It also appears that in English, words that begin with gif are (at least in the majority) derived from gift, so it seems like that the letter cluster "gif" at the beginning of the word or in this case the whole word, is almost exclusive enunciated with a hard g.

Here‚Äôs my take: In English, G before an i or an e tends be pronounced soft if the word is of French/Latin origin and hard if the word is of Germanic origin. If you break down GIF (graphic interchange format), all of those words ultimately originate from Latin. Therefore, GIF is a Latin-derived word, so a soft G should be correct.

The answer is a lot more simple: the letters are in fact pronounced separately since it is an acronym for "Graphics Interchange Format" and not an abbreviation for "Graphicsinterchangeformat". Although we can make it more simple and combine the letters when pronouncing it, but if we do so, we have to think that we are combining the letters "G" (which on its own is pronounced as _ í_ and not _g_), "I" and "F" and not parts of the word.

I argue that the words with "gi" pronounced as /d í…™/ are mostly Latin or French words. A word like "garage" is from French where the soft or hard "g" is shown in the vowel which follows. "Ga" is hard while "ge" is soft. But in native English words, the "g" is hard regardless of vowel. Gather, gall, got, get, gut, good, goo, giddy... Also, I don't know why you said "gib" is pronounced as /d í…™b/... It's /…°…™b/

To add, since g is technically supposed to be like j when followed by e, i, y, or ae, u is placed between g and said vowels to signify that it no longer sounds like j, just like in the Romance languages. This makes sense considering g NEVER sounds like j when followed by a u (or really any letter that‚Äôs not e, i, y, or the ae combo).  Examples of this would be guess, guide, and guy.

It‚Äôs pronounced gif not jif. And no, just because the creator of the word chooses to pronounce it incorrectly, doesn‚Äôt make it correct.
Who owned the copyright, and there is your answer. LZW algorithm that made GIFs possible was actually under patent, owned by a company called Unisys Corp. And in 1995, after years of developers having a free-for-all with their GIFs, suddenly Unisys wanted to make good on their patent. They announced they would be charging a small royalty (.45 percent and .65 percent on different products) for software that used the algorithm, including TIFF and PDF as well as GIF. Their patent wouldn‚Äôt run out until 2003 in the U.S. and 2004 everywhere else.

It's "Gif" because in the event that someone made a graphics format that was somehow ".jif", it'd be pronounced "jiff" and thus the pronunciation of ".gif" needs to be "giff" in order to be more accurate and not confusing. It doesn't actually matter if the format exists or not ‚Äì what matters is both future proofing and precision. If a letter has two pronunciations, it's better to choose the one that's more unique to that letter.

I'm obviously no linguistics expert, but from what I understand, GI is pronounced with G, not J.  The F here is subordinate and not relevant to the issue.  That being said, I recall learning that Chi is the English interpretation of a single Chinese letter.  The point is that when translating something across languages, information, or sound, or some other aspect can be lost in translation or understanding.  That being said, the Inventer of the format is American.  Americans are a whole range of complicated in their language.  But then dialects in the UK are not much different if you are not prepared for them.  So maybe it is pronounced with a J in his community.  But the general majority outside of that says it with a G.  So it seems to be down to a localised issue of how it should be said, relative to how other people in your area might pronounce other words.

If you have to use the word "JIF" that starts with a J to explain the way its pronounced, then you're doing it wrong. GIF is closest to the word GIFT, which isn't pronounced JIFT (again note the J), so most people are going to pronounce it like GIFT without the T. Even GIVE doesn't have the "J" sound, so you have to do some mental gymnastics to get there.

I know why I went with hard G.  As far as I'm concerned, "Jif" is in the peanut butter aisle.  So I locked in the pronunciation that's didn't sound like you could spread it on a slice of bread.
People have not looked at this properly if they're only looking at words starting with "G" or "GI". Every other word in the English language which contains the word "GIF", are all pronounced GIF, not JIF. There are 19 words that contain the word "GIF", 18 of those 19 are some variation of "GIFT" (gifted, gifting, giftware etc), however there is one exception, that word is "FUNGIFORM", and though being unrelated, the "GIF" part is still pronounced GIF. In conclusion, there is no example in the English language where the word GIF appears pronounced as JIF.

I think the international aspect is important. In Denmark, g is, as far as I can currently recall, almost always pronounced hard "guh" rather than "djuh". Giraffe is Giraf, unlike in English where it's more like "Djiraf". As such, as I read GIF, it's a hard G for me. That means that, if my experience is representative, you have an entire country - maybe even the entirety of Scandinavia, maybe Germany too - that all have the same interpretation because of how their languages sound. The internet may speak English, but it does so internationally, so when we count pronounciation of an internet-spread word, it will not necessarily conform to usual English rules.

Its pronunciation will not change the way how we'd use that data, it will not extend it's probably short lifetime... it just doesn't matter, it's only data for an image, and only for a short while, obsolete in a few years, actually it was already obsolete... In Russian to pronounce gif as "jif" you need to use 4 letters (–¥–∂–∏—Ñ) when "gif" pronunciation takes only 3 (–≥–∏—Ñ). That's why Russians call it "gif" and during learning English we usually stuck to more common pronunciation. Maybe other languages have some similar cases for debatable words like this.

Well when i was lewrning french i say "jif" Then when i learned english i say it "GIF"
The issue with using "there's no wrong pronunciation" with GIF, is that it's technical lanugage. It refers to a very specific definition. When you pronounce it however you feel like, it degrades the value of the word in a way that regular language doesn't. .Gif and .Jif. If you prononce Gif with a soft J, there's no way to tell those two files apart, and they're both image formats used. If you ask someone who pronounced GIF with a J sound to "save the file as a jiff" then there's not definite right choice, and picking the wrong choice could render the whole thing nonfunctional. This doesn't matter a whole lot with an image file (at least I think), but imagine these kinds of mistakes between two surgeons in the operating theatre, or between two engineers in a power plant.  Technical language as a tool requires a far greater degree of specifcity than regular language, so there has to be an agreed "right or wrong"  pronunciation.

It's pronounced "Gif" and NOT "Jif" and here's why: Gif = Gif (Literal word, pronunciation) Gif does not = Jif (Literal word vs pronunciation) The word "Gif" is closest to the word "Gift". We pronounce "Gift" as "Gif" with a t sound at the end. Gift. We don't say "Jift" nor do we spell it "Jift".  Here is the literal proof: G = Guh J = Juh Gif has G Guh-if Gif

This isn't about the total number of words which start with gi-, it's about the fact that gift is pronounced with a hard g and there are no English words that start with gif- that are pronounced with a soft g.  The word gift is the one and only closest point of evidence, and therefore determines the language rule which GIF should follow for an English speaker.  I respect the inventor's ability to program a delightful image format, but not his ability to pronounce things.

"Turns out you invented a word you don't get to make the call on how it's pronounced."  Isn't that precisely the problem? It's not an invented word, it's an acronym. "Graphical" has a hard G, therefore GIF has a hard G. End of story
The problem with even remotely considering GIF with a soft G is that there is a legacy format for the JPEG standard - JIF. Which unlike GIF doesn't really have any alternative pronunciation.  Admittedly the term Graphics Interchange Format existed 5 years before JPEG Interchange Format, but clearly nobody cared in 1992, so do you think anybody outside of Steve Wilhite cares now?

When you say Gem... do you say "Gehem"? NO. It's "Jem" with a soft G. Period.
Unlike many words which have vague origins, GIF is a name. If someone pronounces your name incorrectly, can they argue they are correct and you are wrong? Of course not. The original specification from compuserve specified how gif is pronounced, therefore that is the correct pronunciation. It has never been 'open for debate' because from its creation it had a specified pronunciation.   While you may be understood if you use the other pronunciation, it is still incorrect. There is no shame in mispronouncing a name because you do not know the correct pronunciation. But it is rude to continue to purposely mispronounce a name after you have been corrected.  There are two correct ways to pronounce the word 'data', but only one correct way to address the android named Data. Search on youtube for "One is my name. The other is not."

If the person who made a word actually got the final say in how it is pronounced, "UFO" would be pronounced "yoo-foh" instead of how we actually pronounce it as "yoo-eff-oh".  At least not in English. The loan word in Japanese, however, *is* pronounced "yoo-foh", and the loan word in Mandarin Chinese is amusingly pronounced "yoh-foo" due to restrictions in syllable construction.  So there's your trivia for the day.

Why is ‚Äúgaffer‚Äù on that list? There‚Äôs no ‚Äúi‚Äù or ‚Äúe‚Äù after the ‚Äúg‚Äù, so why would there be any ambiguity between the hard and soft ‚Äúg‚Äù sound in that case?
I can make my own rules, it's pronounced gif
I remember doing a research paper about the pronunciation of this word in Uni. The main point I found was that in the English language words which start with "gi" are pronounced with a soft 'g' (as a 'j') *UNLESS* they are imported words, generally of Germanic origin (such as 'gift' which comes to English for the old Germanic language). Since 'gif' is not a germanic origin word, it should follow the more general rule since it doesn't fit in the 'exception', if you're just going off of basic pronunciation rules at least.

Subjectively, pronouncing 'g' as 'j' feels like an old-fashioned habit peculiar to English, and maybe more educated people are subtly aware that when they stumble upon a new word that going hard g is more likely to be correct given the usage of g in several other major Latin alphabet languages. Infamously, few people say 'jigawatts' these days, perhaps because it is a term that is only relatively recently come into common usage as well as being a scientific term with which one would be more conscious of Latin/Greek roots.

Does psycholinguistics take into account whether your brain already has, essentially, already allotted a place for a given pronunciation?  If I look at a word with two possible pronunciations and I'm already using one for something else (e.g., Jif brand peanut butter), I might be less likely to add a homophone to my lexicon than just to create a new pronunciation. It seems easier.  My mom exclusively bought Jif peanut butter. And, for some reason, my family just said Jif instead of peanut butter (a la Chapstick for lip balm or Kleenex for tissues). "Are we  out of Jif?" was a common sentence in our house in the 90s.  tl;dr I wonder if people who were already familiar with using the Jif pronunciation for peanut butter are more likely to be in the Gif pronunciation camp.

The correct answer, is, of course, jaife.
It's a common problem with acronyms. The general understanding is that the common usage of the acronyms pronunciation need have nothing to do with the words that the acronym represents. So if you want to say Jiff when referring to Graphical Information Format (GIF) you are perfectly justified and anyone who has a problem can go soak their head.  This isn't the only acronym with this problem. In fact, most acronyms beginning with hard diphthongs like gr, gl, sh, gw, and ch will probably have this issue.
I'm on the side of if the person who invented it says it's pronounced a certain way, that way in undoubtedly the correct way.  Like, my name is Gian.  It's pronounced like John and has been for who knows how long that name has existed.
If you narrow it down to a techie context, hard g is more consistent based on gig(abyte) and git (source control), and also disambiguates pronunciation of the .jif file extension.

If we want to get really pedantic... I don't like how GIF is considered a "lossless format"... Most GIF's have literally transparent sections if the pixels do not change. You might argue that if the pixels do not change, they don't need to be there... But it still is a loss of information. Data is literally not present, and it relies on other data to be present, in order to look how it is supposed to look. Information can be reconstructed, yes, but the actual information has been lost. It is not there... Hence, it is lost.

I'm going with "Giff" because "Jiff" doesn't sound right unless it's described as a noun which it isn't. Reasoning for this that my brain seems to like is [G] => [GI] => [GIF](t). The only words I know that have the letter pattern of G, followed by I, followed by F, is "Gift" for example. Add more letters and things start to get a little bit fucky, however: Gif[(t), (fy), (fgaff)] but generally the only* word one comes up with beyond the f is generally "gift" which creates it's association in my mind. I don't know of any other words that start with "gif" that are pronounced with a hard "j" sound other than "giffy".  In a word comparison of 2 to 1, "Giff" sounds the most correct to me. But you know, English is stupid with it's 300 million exceptions for everything. All these stupid little nuanced pairings of letters changing how you pronounce something is rather annoying and a nightmare for anyone attempting to bloody well learn it.

It also depends on the reader's background. For exemple, if they have a non English mother tongue. In my language, for example, it is the rule that a 'g' followed by an 'i' will always be pronounced as "ji", and if you want the pronunciation to be "gi" as in "gift", you need to put a 'u' in between the 'g' and the 'i' (so you'd write "gui" to make it sound as in "gift"). That would make it such that I would have a tendency to read "gif" as "jif".

I analyze this differently, start with the options of how to pronunciation the word, then determine what are the ways that pronunciation could be spelled. If one pronunciation could be spelled only one way and that is the spelling, then that is the pronunciation. Since gif can only be spelled gif and jif could be spelled jif or gif, gif must be pronounced gif.

Its both so shut up now
As someone who speaks multiple languages and still aspiring to learn more, english pronounciation vs writing is an annoyance that has been growing over time. It is so inconsistent depending on where the words _came from_ and the pronounciation rules of that language, but not with enough consistency. If the origin is a germanic language for example, GI would be pronounced GI and not JI. But if it's one of the latin languages probably JI. Most languages have some ambiguity in pronounciation, but english is FAR beyond other european languages in the inconsistency. Even the spelling of single letters often missmatch how they are pronounced in words, and the rules for diphthongs are not clear. Also, most english vowels are diphthongs while most european languages have monophthong vowels, which makes english accents in those languages sound very different from all other accents.  Just to end on a rant note and throw a random language under the buss, i'm happy Danish isn't the dominant international language. "R√∏dgr√∏d med fl√∏de" sounds like someone struggling to not throw up :P

Here's the thing -- what reason do we have to use "jif"?  Sure, there are lots of words where a soft G precedes an I, but there are many words where a hard G precedes an I as well -- so that's not really any reason to say "jif" -- & Wilhite says it's "jif"?  So what, sorry, don't care, Wilhite is not the boss of my language -- the simple fact is that, in modern times, if someone invents a new English word & wants it to start w/ a J sound, they will spell that word w/ a J, not a G -- something that Wilhite didn't have the option for, since there's no such thing as "jraphics" -- I'm just not seeing any good reason to pronounce it "jif" -- especially when, as many have pointed out, the G in GIF is taken from a hard-G word -- see, I just don't put a lot of stock in the other acronyms used as counter-examples -- in the case of SCUBA & LASER, the difference between "uh" & "oo" is very slight, requiring only a modest adjustment of the lips &, likewise, the difference between an S & a Z is just a small shift of the tongue [sidebar, the P in JPEG is inconsequential, because it's not the P that makes the F sound in "photo", it's the combination of the P & the H -- if they wanted us to say "jay-feg", they should've made the acronym "JPhG"] -- but G & J are very different sounds, w/ J being expressed at the front of the mouth, & G happening toward the throat -- y'know, there should actually be 2 different letters, to represent those very different sounds...oh, wait!  There already *are* different letters!  G, & J!  Now obviously, we're not going to go back through the whole English language, & respell all the soft-G words w/ a J -- but, moving forward, we can at least make sure that all newly-minted words match up, keeping the letter G for the hard G sound & the letter J for the soft G sound -- & hard-G GIF is part of that moving forward -- so give the gift of GIFs, you giddy gits!

Why has has to be GIF but not ‚ÄúGee Ai Eff‚Äù
I prefer the hard G pronunciation for two reasons.   One is the the word "gif" is MOST similar to in written form is "gift" which is pronounced with the hard G.    Secondly, the purpose of language is to communicate meaning from one person to another, so the less ambiguity the better.   Hearing "Gif" with a hard G immediately tells the listener you are talking about the file type.    Hearing "Jif" requires more context to know whether we are talking about file types or yummy peanut butter.

I'm not convinced that descriptivism should prevent value judgement.  I know this is a tangent from the pronunciation of .gif, but consider two questions:  A)  "Where's the washroom?"  B)  "Where's the shitter?"  Those sentences are semantically identical, but choosing the latter option will lead people to make certain inferences about the speaker's personality.

Hold on, hold on:  *"LASER" IS AN ACRONYM?*
00:35  You've already made a fatal error.  GIF is not a simple word.  It's a proper noun.  A trademarked name, in fact.  Names have only one correct pronunciation, which is decided by their owners.  In this case, the owner of the trademarked name GIF says it's "jiff".  That's the end of the argument.  Unless you think I'm correct to say that your name is pronounced "tome shcotey", if only I can get a large number of people to agree with me.  I could also debunk every single claim for why a hard 'g' makes more sense, or a soft 'g' doesn't make sense, but I don't want to start writing a novella.  Suffice it to say, there are no legitimate arguments for why a hard 'g' is superior to a soft 'g', or why a soft 'g' doesn't make sense.
Yesterday I was listening to a debate about BBC impartiality leading to the equal platforming of "expert" and "vox pop" opinions. The argument was that a determination to pursue impartiality had led the BBC to give the impression that both views were equally, erm, "true". (Sorry for the quote marks, but these are the times we live in). Having watched this video I wonder if the root of the problem is that we, as a society, have confused descriptivism (as practiced by dictionary makers, eg) with impartiality (as practiced by journalists, eg). Would it be possible to tease this out so as to provide a clearer guidance to broadcasters on how to construct impartiality for these intemperate times? Just wondrin' ...

Sooo... you're trying to reignite this argument? :D  It's "jif".
Jif is a brand of peanut butter in the U.S. The reason why gif is pronounced with a hard G, is because the other sound was more commonly used to refer to the peanut butter, not the format, and the hard G began to dominate to avoid homophonic collision with the proper noun.

The correct way of pronouncing it could probably only be determined by analysing any single parallel reality and counting how often gif or jif is more common. Theres a slight issue with that. There being an infinite number of parallel realities the result would probably be more or less exactly 50/50
It would also be worth examining the words based on their origins - English is a language built out of other languages, but how are 'gi' words treated in words that originated in English? Gift has a Norse root, gist is originally from a Latin root (Romance languages), and the way the G is pronounced often has more to do with where the word came from when it was added to English than anything else, acronyms on the other hand are built int the language itself, not loaned from elsewhere.  When I was younger in the earlier days of computer science it was / §/ and I still will pronounce it as such. The pronunciation may be changing because more people are reading the word from the format before they hear it mentioned and making a (wrong in my opinion) judgement on the way it is pronounced, but it wasn't until (relatively) recently that I ever heard the hard G pronunciation (and have never heard a good argument for changing to that)

It‚Äôs an acronym. Acronyms are often pronounced with letter sounds.
This weird phenomena where the G letter (from a G sounding word) should sometimes sound like J, is indeed a very weird quirk of written text of some cultures. Had the writing system been better formalized to avoid this ambiguity, this wouldn't have been a problem. Think about it, if you had to re-invent the alphabet, you would be mental to put in a rule where the same symbol would produce a different sound (depending on context), specially when one of those sounds already has different a symbol specifically dedicated for it. And yes, you should read it JFEG

Acronyms *are* pronounced according to what they stand for *unless* the resulting pronunciation is unnatural. Pronouncing "laser" as "lasser" is "acronymically" correct, but unnatural, so we modify it. Pronouncing "jpeg" as "jaypheg" would make no sense at all, so we modify it. But there's no need to modify "gif" to "jif". The hard G is the "acronymically" correct version, and also perfectly natural, so there's no sensible reason to change it to "jif".

In the interests of clarity, here' something I learned a while ago whilst researching this (albeit only with Google and Wikipedia searches; there's your poor citations): *.gif (pronunced /…°…™f/ by myself at least) is the file extension used predominantly for an animated image using LZW compression; I leave out *.gifv which is the newer HTML5 equivalent and does not count as a pure *.gif file as it is a video not an image encoded with MPEG-4 or WEBM. *.jif (pronounced /d í…™f/ by myself at least) is an old and mostly outdated extension for static JPEG images used in the 1990's. That being said, if you can use whatever pronunciation you wish... as long as its /…°…™f/ üòù

This whole confusion about pronunciations in the English language is caused by the pathetic Roman script that most European languages use. The Romans gave many great things to humanity but writing was not one of them. The number system was especially bad and humanity would not have so much progress if the Arabs traders had not spread the Indian/ Hindu numerals to the west.   Most Indian languages (and perhaps more around the world that I am not aware of) have such a precise script (Like Devanagari)  that it is simply not possible to mispronounce anything written in them. There is not even a scope of having a game like spelling bee in Hindi for example. One does not even need a spell checker - only predictive text!  There is one and only one clear way of writing something being said or reading something that's written.  In Devnagri script, Steve Wilhite could / would  have already written it as "‡§ó‡§ø‡§´ " rather than "‡§ú‡§ø‡§´" - no scope of confusion there.  Its extremely ironic that Indian kids seems to do so well in spelling bee competitions.
Everyone in the comments using misspellings of words to provide their point in the same tired old way people have got years:   Where's the lojic? Actually watch the video. Accept that both are acceptable, and use the one you prefer.

The problem here is that English is not deterministic when it comes to the relationship between speech and writing. In other languages, such as my native language Italian, there is no ambiguity and when you read a word you instantly know how to pronounce it (except for accent, but that's another story). I guess this problem is caused by how old English is a standardized language, so that the speech has evolved while the written form has not (or vice versa, I don't know).  Btw in Italy we mostly say "gif", with soft g, because it's the rule in Italian, so it sounds more natural to us.

I don't care how you say it as long as I understand what you're talking about. Also I tend to change how I say it depending on language. In French (my native language) I tend to pronounce it 'jif' while in English, I pronounce it 'g if' because in French, a 'g' and a 'i' together make the sound 'j' unless there is a 'u' between them. The 'u' stays silent but the 'g' changes its pronounciation.

In my language, you can only use hard Gs before the vowels ‚Äúa‚Äù, ‚Äúo‚Äù and ‚Äúu‚Äù. If you wanted a hard G before the vowels ‚Äúe‚Äù and ‚Äúi‚Äù, you‚Äôd have to add an ‚Äúu‚Äù between them, like so: ‚ÄúGuif‚Äù. Therefore, if GIFs had been invented in my country, they would certainly be pronounced like ‚Äújif‚Äù. They weren‚Äôt, so I still use the hard G in GIF, because it sounds better
People think stuff like this is pedantic but try to mispronounce words when over radio communications and it's possible to get someone killed. Small details matter, granted usually only in uncommon circumstances. One argument I never hear anyone talk about is the actual functional advantage of 'gif' vs 'jif', which is what other words you may confuse them with. Gift sounds very much like the word gif, and can be used in the exact same context. "I sent you a gif" could easily be misheard as "I sent you a gift", whereas nobody is going to assume "I sent you a 'jif'" means I sent you a brand of peanut butter.

Either it's a Christmas present or it's peanut butter.
"JIF" is a peanut butter brand, not a graphic interface file.
The makers of JIF peanut butter get it. "JIF" being a word they chose for their peanut butter because it was easy to spell, say, and remember. At the time Jiff or Jiffy would have been a common place term meaning 'a moment' or 'in a moment'. So there was already an association for people to make (like Having JIF peanut butter being part of a quick meal). If they wanted to make things hard they would have spelled it GIF. Because G has two possible ways of saying it. And that's a problem. We already have the letter J. We don't need a letter that has it's own pronunciation, but also sometimes sounds like J. If we want to use the J sound we should spell words that we want to use it in with a J. Greater consistency makes it easier to learn and increases their utility. I think the rule about not having such rules is a bad rule.  Also the letters in acronyms should make the same sound that they do in the words they stand for. There isn't a good reason why they shouldn't and it would mean that making Acronyms becomes elevated from convenience to poetry (if you pair it with rules like not using representing conjunctives in an acronym or always trying to make it sound like a word). Additionally I'd almost be willing to bet that it would make what the letters stand for in an acronym easier to remember.  ...I'm going to keep say Gif with a hard G. Because G is a bastard letter and needs to be put in it's place.

Last name starts with a G. So, we named my kid Jenevieve not Genevieve. Didn‚Äôt want the G making different sounds. Also because initials would have been EGG.
So as per the language rules explained here, it's a popularity contest... Except there are many words that have 2 accepted pronunciations so why not "GIF"? If you follow the logical path of this popularity rule then you realise that there is a certain balance that legitimises both pronunciations and "GIF" would seem to be in that zone - Although other words with multiple pronunciations probably don't differ on the starting sound. If you consider other words that have had a change in pronunciation then you'd realise that by necessity there had to be a period where the new pronunciation was the less popular one until it gained popularity for some reason. With this in mind it's clear that the organic nature of such language shifts has to leave room for alternate pronunciations.

2:42 I think you got those backwards.
Little problem here: all these considerations are anglocentric. GIF is an acronym of three English words, but being also a file name extension and and international standard, is used in every other language on earth. Consequently, the pronunciation will also be determined by the native language of the speaker. As an Italian, I always pronounced GIF with a soft G, because in Italian *every* G followed by an I is soft. To have a hard G, we insert an H, so for the G to be hard it would be written as GHIF. On the opposite, to have a soft G in front of (for example) an A, we insert an I.  Hard Gs: GA, GHE, GHI, GO, GU. Soft Gs: GIA, GE, GI, GIO, GIU. So it's a soft G for me.

The answer is: we are lazy and try to "pronounce" acronyms like they are words, which they aren't. Some eventually become words, but these shouldn't (even if they have). There will eventually be so many image and video formats (most steadily becoming virtually obsolete) that it would be a waste of time, brain, and dictionaries to retain specific definitions and pronunciations of everything for any other reason than historical archive reference.

The problem with GIF is that if you treat it like a word (rather than an acronym) the only other words in the English language which start with "gif" are all derivatives of the word "gift", so the pattern-matching parts of our brains will prefer the hard G. The only people, so far as I can fathom,  who prefer the soft g are Americans who wish they were eating JIF Peanut Butter instead of dealing with linguistics or file formats.

In French j and g pronunciation is swapped from English. I wonder if there is similar distribution of /g…™f/|/ §…™f/ in bilingual speakers?
Put it simply, words should be spelt as said, not spelt/said with some stupid "rules" that make it confusing. Non-native speakers already struggle to learn English because of how stupid our rules are, how many of them contradict each other or how oddly they change things. If we want to make our language better, we shouldn't be arguing about how we pronounce something, but instead how non-native speakers would attempt to pronounce it with minimal assistance. Think about the logic before we think about what we are comfortable with or what rules exist, remember "I before E except after C"? What about *science*, a word that is the very foundation of most things we understand, kinda *weird* if you ask me... Sure, it's not a "solid rule", but it clearly does not help with logic. Does anyone else have a false memory of a well-known, lightly-abrasive cream cleaner going through a name change from "Jif", via "Gif", to "Cif", and of that being the reason why they pronounce it GIF?  The product did change from "Jif" to "Cif", but as far as I can tell, "Gif" was a figment of my imaginiation. What I think actually happened is that I saw "GIF" on the computer and, being recently aware of the Jif name change, I thought "Ahh, GIF: like the renamed cleaning product! Wait, is it Gif now, or something else?" Then I went to the kitchen and saw that it was, in fact, "Cif", but by that time the association was already set and ever since then I have called it "GIF, like the cleaning product", because, if they had renamed it to "Gif" instead of "Cif", that is definitely how people would have pronounced it.

"Turns out, even if you invented a word, you don't get to make the call on how it's pronounced." I have said this before and I will stand by it now: Yes you do. If you invent a word, you DO get to make the call on how it SHOULD be pronounced. You can't force everyone to use the same pronunciation, but if you come up with a word, you DO get to say how it SHOULD be pronounced. My example is names: It's your name, you get to pick how it's pronounced. Sure, you can't enforce that pronounciation on everyone, but you can make a "correct" way to pronounce it; what people should say.  tl; dr: If the inventor of GIF says it's "JIF", then we should say JIF, but you can't force everyone to say "JIF".
"Gib" is also frequently disputed for much the same reasons (although in this case the word is short for "giblets")

This is all because the modern English language is a clusterfuck party, historically filled with loan words and incorporated words originating from several unrelated as well as several related language groups and now with such a global reach English is spoken across the planet by populations with vastly differing cultures and languages. Even among those within a single country the language is also morphed by regional dialect full of vowel shifts and what have you. This debate about what word is pronounced in what way being "correct" will likely never end. Language changes with us as we change.

As a sci fi fan (and would-be author) I tend to take a long-term view on a lot of things, and this is one of them. You may think descriptivism is a good thing, but wait until people start living for two, or maybe three, hundred years. You think old people who complain about language change are in a minority? Wait until they aren't! Then we'll have a rather interesting problem to solve.

"Unless you are very young [...]" This, as someone who is older than GIF, is a large source of the issue and my argument against "the creator's intent" mattering.  We were using GIFs and locking in that preferred pronunciation more than two decades before we had easy access to a shared web where audio, and the creator's pronouncements, were suddenly accessible.  At that point, it's too late to correct anyone, and he's lost any meaningful ownership or ability to steer it.    On top of all that, his intended "pun" on the popular peanut product slogan is not especially good. ;)
If you can use "g" for the hard sound and "j" for the soft one, why do you insist on using both?

English rules are very specific!  It's the soft 'g'. The general rule is this: if the letter after 'g' is 'e', 'i' or 'y', the pronunciation is a 'soft g' as in 'fringe' or 'geoff'.

I think there is an international aspect to it, too.  To go by a personal example: I'm Hungarian, born in 1991, been using computers since 1997. At the beginning I only had a very rudimentary knowledge of English, especially since Windows was available in Hungarian even back then. So, the file extensions' pronunciations burned in my brain according to Hungarian acronym rules: it's gif as in git for me, and jpeg is jay-peg (in which the jay evolved -- in English context -- to this English jay from the Hungarian j).  P.S.: Hungarian is very heavily prescriptivist and has been for many decades. So I tend to follow not what the word creator or the language users say, but what the Academy says, since theirs is the final, official word. And there is a very interesting bouncing back and forth of how the Academy elevates new language use patterns into official status and how newly created correct grammar spreads among the population. So if you want new or different features in Hungarian, there are two ways to it: convince a huge amount of language users to adopt it and eventually the Academy may make it official, or go directly to the Academy and convince them.
Gif as in Gift is the most compelling argument I've heard.

It's always interesting to me when people insist that words/names that are romanized from a language with a syllabary-based writing system are pronounced one way or another. There's 2 common arguments the jif camp uses, but they're both easily countered. For those curious they are:  1a. The creator said it's pronounced as jif, so it is jif. 1b. The English language is full of precedents where a word is pronounced differently than how the creator intended. That's how language works.  2a. Giraffe/gin/etc is with a jif. 2b. Gift literally has the word gif in it, and how is that pronounced? Gift takes priority over any other similar words.

(What I mean is: in some languages, to read any letter all you need to know are classifications of the letter before and after, thus there is only one way to read a word - and only one way to write it down (one of such languages is Russian, the other is Thai))

Linguists should not say how things should be? Really now? That is directly working against the purpose of language. Without a ground truth from which all people derive their understanding of words and grammar, there will be a less than ideal transfer of thought by nature. Degradation of a language is a thing.   The logical conclusion to that line of thinking is that there should be no language school teaching people how to write and speak because that is telling "from on high" what is the correct way to speak.

Modern english has soft and hard vowels, which mostly just have interactions with the consonants C and G. E, I, and Y are soft vowels, and A, O, and U are hard vowels. That's why you get a K sound for call, count, and curb, but an S sound for cent, cite, and cycle. Likewise, you get a hard G for game, goal, and gun, but a soft G for gel, gym, and gif.  The older you go for the origin of words, the more exceptions you get to this rule, which is why I say modern English.
I'm really glad you didn't give a definitive answer to this. While I may pronounce it GIF, I respect the people who pronounce it GIF.

It's the same way that no matter which side of the Atlantic you're on, English-speakers recognize that "herb" and "erb" or "alum-in-um" and "alu-mini-um" are the same.

I hate how linguists try to apply descriptivism outside of linguistics.  Of COURSE the study of language must study what exists and simply analyze and describe.  But the native speakers can and must collectively enforce a 'right way to say it' approach.  Otherwise language would be too fluid and error-based to fulfill its basic function of enhancing communication.  Teaching would certainly be impossible.  Trying to enforce descriptivism outside of linguistics is exactly as counterproductive as trying to use prescriptivism inside it.  That said, I use and support the soft sound because it's just easier to say in the sentences where I often used it as a child.
/ ía…™f/ for life      Serious talk: The correctness of a pronunciation is proportional to the ease with which it's understood (and, though it's rarely a significant factor, the ease with which it's spoken). Neither pronunciation of 'gif' can reasonably be considered "wrong".

I come down on the hard G side for orthographic reasons that always seemed sufficiently good to me, but I admit are slipping a little....  But as far as descriptivism is concerned? The entire purpose of language is to allow people to communicate. For that to be possible, everybody has to have the same mappings from word to concept. Descriptivism throws that entire idea in the toilet, and hence, I cannot, at the tactical level, give it any credence whatever.  Up at the thirty thousand foot, 10-year level, fine. Languages adapt. But that isn't what descriptivism is advocating. At least not as far as I've been able to discern.   Prescriptivism forever!
Gif is gif not jif if it wanted to be jif it should be spelled jif!
I‚Äòm German therefore I take the hard g
Has anyone done any research into exactly when the hard-G pronunciation became common? When I was a kid everyone know how to pronounce gif. When I was in college in the late 90s the campus computer club had a recruitment poster that said "Choosey geeks choose .GIF" which is a joke that only works if everyone knows that the GIF is pronounced with a soft G. I didn't even realize that people were mispronouncing it until like 2013 or so, by which point the hard-G pronunciation had seemingly become ubiquitous. I would really like to know exactly when & how that change occurred.
The correct answer is ofcourse : G  I  F
The fact that we have the word "gift," in which the 't' is practically silent in most American pronunciations, at least, is the most definitive determinant here. There is also the fact that we have words "jiff," "jiffy" which are spelled with a 'j', strongly implying that if it were a phonetic word and it was pronounced with 'dz' sound, it would end up getting spelled as "jif". When pattern matching, the human brain will focus on similarity and commonality, so the fact that there are a pile of other words in language that also start with 'gi' matters little if they are both less common and less similar to the obvious examples. So trying to prove that majority should be pronouncing it like "jiff" instead of like "gift" is an absolutely a lost cause. And, well, statistics reflect exactly that.
I liked where you were talking about how our brains decided to pronounce it, because I think the way I pronounce it is due to my synaesthesia. G with a hard G sound is greenish-yellow which better matches the yellow of I and the green of F. Pronouncing it as Jif, the J sound is more murky blue-purple which definitely doesn‚Äôt fit the vibes of the rest of the word. I think my brain saw the word and subconsciously defaulted to a pronunciation where the sounds have the most similar colours, gif rather than jif.

The simple robust solution is to convert dictionaries for all languages to the Esperanto alphabet and spelling rules(one letter=one sound, one sound=one letter, no digraphs or doubled letters) This solves uncertainty in pronunciation and allows for those wishing to learn another language to focus on the grammar unencumbered by a new set of symbols and spelling rules. It does not have a particularly strong or immediate effect on any spoken language or grammar thus being an easy adaption. There will be some issue with homophones, but this is readily resolved with context(as it already is in spoken language) or with use of Esperanto rules for distinguishing different types and categories of words.(applied only where needed)

I feel like that slide gives away the killer argument in my head. Anyone who pronounces it as jif spells it as jif when they're trying to enforce that pronunciation in your head, but when saying "it's jif not ghif", they spell the latter pronunciation as just gif. As much as people endorse descriptivism, I don't think many people are truly through and through descriptivists in a particular very strong sense of the term (though maybe the sense I'm talking about isn't one that anyone actually means and I'm just misinterpreting how people sometimes describe descriptivism?). Almost everyone has some preferences about how people use different words, especially when it comes to politics (I could give an example, but by the nature of political/partisan disagreements, it would be contentious, and while I could describe it in a neutral manner, I don't trust the comment section to not make the political disagreement the topic, so I will not give the example). Now, in the weaker sense of "doesn't claim that there is an  *objectively correct* use of a term/word", sure, there may be many "descriptivists", but I think most people, or at least most people who are very online, have at least one strong opinion about how they prefer some word to be used.  And that's my justification for "Yes, I *still* prefer that people not use the word 'literally' as emphasis. And I'm not some backwards prescriptivist for having that preference. It is a preference, not a belief. And if I slip up and do so on accident, please call me out in it."

There was once a time (most of the 90s) when it was only pronounced "jiff". If you said "gyff", you were either misunderstood or laughed at for not knowing how to pronounce it right. At this point, both pronunciations are recognized and understood so it doesn't really matter, but I do think that most of the people that feel passionately about it being pronounced "jiff" do so because they've been using the format since it's inception and remember that time. I don't really care, but there's still that bit in my head that immediately reacts in a "heh, noob" sort of way when I hear it pronounced "gyff".

0:32 As you say, a principle of linguistics is descriptivism. But "There should be no value judgement..."? This is too sweeping. That principle, as applied to _language_, applies only in the context of _linguistics_. Linguists may, if they choose, stick to describing past usage and not state judgements about it, but that doesn't stop me or anyone else from saying that a particular usage is right or wrong. Or misleading, or absurd, or any other criticism. 1:35 Get out, "gaffer". G can't possibly be soft before "a". 1:51 But doesn't "gift" derive from "give"?

The big thing missed here is that GIF isn't really an exclusively English word. It's not like it's the kind of word you learn in an English class so the pronounciation is going to be very influenced by what native speakers of other languages intuit the English pronounciation of it should be.
my name is jif
It's pronounced with a hard G, because the majority of the world speaks languages other than English, and G is not necessarily a homophone of J in those instances (except some Romance languages). It also does not necessarily have to be pronounced with a hard G as in _gear,_ because some languages have absolutely inconceivable ways of pronouncing the vowel that the letter G is meant to represent. It is also pronounced with a _jelly_ G, because... who says it isn't? Or rather than _says,_ who does _enforce it?_ And _how_ do they enforce it?   Who is the sole enforcer of linguistic rules? Is this question even relevant? Or is it proof that there can indeed be stupid questions?

A point you didn't consider: GIF, being an acronym, isn't only an English word anymore.  It doesn't have its own word in other languages. When most people see it they will assume it's "gif" rather than "jif" because g's aren't pronounced as "j" in many languages other than English.

Let's be honest here, no one saw "gif" and thought "oh, it's pronounced jif".  What really happened is that Steve Wilhite is a contrarian and decided to ignore the obvious pronunciation (as evidenced by 0:26), and then a bunch of people that enjoy seeming smart went around saying "ummm axshually the creator said it's pronounced jif".
Descriptivism is a value of linguistics -- it's a value of the scientific study of language. That does not mean that there is something wrong with being a prescriptivist, as I am. Words have meetings, and we should agree on them, standardize them, and enforce that standardization. We can be interested in linguistics, and also think prescriptivism is a better model for language use.
Cool fact: Spanish grammar/vocabulary is not descriptive, we have a "royal academy of the language" that constantly monitors the varieties of the language spoken in the world and periodically publishes a dictionary with accepted words, grammar and pronunciation, pushing aside "corruptions" of the language. For most of the foreigners it's gif and not jif, because in German, Spanish, Polish and probably many other languages g is always pronounced as g and never as j.
I call it G.I.F., it's not jiff or giff as .jpg isn't pronounced japag or jepig.
In romance languages a g followed by an e or an i is almost always pronounced /j/ and I think in my head that is why I understand it to be pronounced as so. Many of English‚Äôs words go by Franco-Romantic conventions especially, where a g followed by an e or i must be followed by a u to be a hard /g/ (e.g. league, rogue, guide, guild), as with most Romance languages. Even our word for the letter g is pronounced /jif/. To me, it seems only the most basic words pronounced with a hard /g/ spelled only with a g when followed by e or i are our old Germanic words, and most newer words follow Romantic conventions. So if GIF was meant to be pronounced with a hard /g/, it would be spelled GUIF.

It's funny, when I read someone prescribing how it's pronounced, without any indication of which pronunciation they mean, I hear it as the peanut butter version, but when I read it in a neutral context I read it as the gift version
The funny thing is pre-mid-2000s, there was no real debate, it was a hard "G" like "Jif". It was only in the later 2000s where the unwashed masses got online and people started using the soft "g" sound, along with phrases like "earl" for URL, that everyone in the technology industry knew was an initialism and not an acronym. Being that there are more new people online than the original pool of people who were online in the late 90s, the new soft "g" usage took over.

You've overlooked the most important consideration: choosy mothers choose Jif.  Jif is peanut butter. A GIF is not peanut butter, therefore it is pronounced with a hard 'G.' And that's the end of that.
Anyone who uses are hard g refuses to acknowledge that g's are softened preceding non-front vowels in English. The problem exists because people use the most commonly used similar-sounding root word 'give' or 'gift' as a means of predicting how to pronounce similarly spelled words. The common occurrence of a word in a language with one spelling does not and has never dictated the way other words in that language are pronounced. If that were the case, we wouldn't have distinct root words with similar spelling - they would all sound the same. It's a soft g, and it's okay for the majority of people to be wrong about something.  Exceptions exist in words with Germanic origin like gift, give, gear, etc. Those exceptions are rare in how they vary, but they are common in their usage. It's wrong and likely not helpful to the growth of a language to homogenize that language's phonetics and grammar based on commonly used words. How can you expect your language to grow without variety and distinctiveness? These phonetic rules exist to ensure distinction, not to erode it. If you love the English language, you will use a soft g in pronouncing gif.
The creator says it‚Äôs supposed to be ‚ÄúJif,‚Äù but I call it gif with a hard ‚Äúg‚Äù because I don‚Äôt want it confused with the peanut butter brand.

See why consistency between pronunciation and spelling is important? In my own language (Italian) the letter "G" can have both the hard and soft pronunciation too, but that's clearly indicated in the spelling: GA, GO and GU are always hard; GE and GI are always soft; if you want a hard G with E or I, just add an H in between: GHE and GHI; and if you want a soft G with A, O or U, you add an I in between: GIA, GIO and GIU. Works exactly the same with C.

How you pronounce it is a population cohort thing.  I pronounce it with a soft G--because I grew up with computers in the 90s and had a level of technical proficiency. People in the 90s who had some technical proficiency (or who wanted to pretend that they did) pronounced it with a soft G. People who pronounced it with a hard G at that time were scrubs who thought the internet and AOL were the same thing. Soft G meant you were in the know.   After all, the creator of the format himself said that it was intentionally a homophone with the peanut butter brand. So if you wanted other computer people to take you seriously, you used the soft G.

My view on the people that are adamant that GIF should be pronounced with a hard G *BECAUSE* the G stands for Graphic which has a hard G should also be the people that pronounce JPEG with an F sound for the P because it stands Photographic.  But I have never found anyone who falls into the former group but adheres to their own rules and falls into the latter group.  I'm *perfectly* fine with people that say should be pronounced with a hard G because it feels right to them, since that's how language evolves.  Whatever language you speak might be unrecognizable if you heard what it used to sound like centuries ago or will sound like centuries from now.  However, I do feel that if you create a word you should have say in how it should be pronounced.

Im a native spanish speaker, and for us is GIF with hard G, because our language is highly descriptive, and how a word is written tells you anything you need to know on how to pronounce it. G only reads as a hard g sound, while the "soft g" sound is represented as a double L, (for us J sounds like the h in hand, so we laugh as jajaja), so the second pronuciation should be written in spanish as "LLIF", and I don't see cat.llif in my _Im√°genes_ folder.

The original tagline from the specification was "choosy developers choose GIF," a play on the old "choosy moms choose JIF" peanut butter commercials from the 70s and 80s. I remember seeing it when I implemented GIF87 support in my graphical BBS system in the late 80s.

It's GIF alright!
I've always been on team jif, and I feel like my reasoning is due to a mixture of local culture and the English language.  Over here, the oldest, most important highway in the country is called the Pan Island Expressway, abbreviated to PIE. No, you don't pronounce it like the pastry. You spell out the acronym letter by letter. P - I - E.   Locals around here have the habit of reading acronyms letter by letter, so every time I hear new three-letter acronyms, I naturally develop the habit of reading them letter by letter. Once I got to the acronym GIF, which when read letter by letter reads jee - eye - eff (because in English, the letter "G" itself is already a soft G), my brain just abbreviated to jif. Jee - eye - eff : jif. Rolls off the tongue a lot better than jee - eye - eff : gif.  I can't speak for everyone, but this is my justification on why I pronounce it as "jif".

Getting on my fuckin nerves... Tom
THANK YOU I've been making that acronym pronunciation argument for years
If you heard gif with a hard g, then looked in the dictionary and couldn't find it, you'd say the dictionary had failed you. Dictionaries, by their nature, describe how language is used, so will be descriptivist. But style guides, which describe how you should use it, are prescriptivist. If you intentionally use a meaning of a word like 'literally' that you know is ambiguous, you're ignoring the primary purpose of communication: making others understand you.  I completely disagree that creators of something don't get to choose it's pronunciation, it's like someone telling you you're pronouncing your own name wrong. People outside of Vietnam typically pronounce 'Nguy·ªÖn' differently to those within Vietnam. So does that mean the pronunciation in other countries, by virtue of being more popular, is right? No. Are NVIDIA wrong to tell us how to pronounce their name in their brand guidelines (which they do)? No. Names and brands aren't bound by the rules of the English language.
90's Kids: Let's just call it the "Pikachu balancing on a Pokeball" format.

It's actually pronounced G.I.F, just like how the FBI and NSA isn't pronounced as fƒì-bi and nƒì-sah respectively.
The hard-G pronunciation makes practical sense:  .gif and .jif are _both_ file extensions used for pictures.  If I had to give technical advice to a graphics designer over the phone, and they needed to know which format was readable by a certain program...not distiguishing a .gif file from a .jif file might cost that designer their job.
I'm German I pronounced it GIF.
Tom, you got the brain part wrong. The brain doesn't look through each and every word similar to gif it remembers, rather it uses the correlations it has learned from its experiences to make a prediction. So it is not looking at the history of the words directly, but rather using the effects that the history has had on the structure of the brain.

‚Äúj‚Äù was the last letter added to the alphabet, wasn‚Äôt it? So why use a legacy system like ‚ÄúsOfT g‚Äù when the newer technology has already taken care of this issue for us?

I did my own study about this where I looked up every single morpheme word that started with <gif>, specifically looking at /…™/ as well, and i got some interesting results. The words that used /g/ tended to be words from germanic origin, and the words that used / §/ tended to come from French or Latin based words. I can't conclude anything from that, but it was just an interesting tidbit that i decided to share.

English pronunciations are so arbitrary that, yes, the person who invents a word DOES get to decide how it's pronounced. Is there any logical reason for the difference in how "ood" is pronounced in "food" and "good"? No. It was literally just arbitrarily decided that was how those words were going to be pronounced. So if the creator of GIF decides it's pronounced like "JIF", that is literally the only qualifier you need. It's "JIF", end of story. You don't get the to change it just because you disagree. It may seem stupid, but this is something that makes English stand out from other languages and why English has limitless possibilities for possible phonetics.

You can also take into account the hardness of the consonant following the 'i'. In "gin" and "gigantic" it's followed by softer consonants where as "give" and "gift" are followed by hard consonants (since the 'f' and 't' are pronounced in the same breath, I'm saying the 'ft' sound is hard, not the f). An 'f' is definitely is a soft vowel, so it must be pronounced "gif" not "ghiff".

Isn't it also about the origin of the word that decides how it should be pronounced? For example in French, "gi" would be pronunced "ji", whereas "ga" would be pronunced with the g sound. That is why the French word "girafe" is pronouced like "jirafe", which is why also the English word is now pronounced this way. In contrast, Germanic words don't follow this rule, e.g., "gift". "gif" originated in English, therefore it should be compared to other English-origin "gi..." words, not to those that originated in another language (French, Spanish, Latin, ...).

As a German, we don't have words (as far as I am aware), that start with a "g" and are not pronounced with a "g", so I am firmly in the "gif" not "jif" camp.
The problem with allowing the most common pronunciation to prevail, is that the notion presupposes all users of a language are about equal in their ability to generate plausible usage. If this premise is false, then a majority of users can conceivably employ a usage or pronunciation which is simply not colorable. Where that occurs, remains a valid role for scholarship.

I think it might be worth mentioning that "Jif" is a popular brand of peanut butter in parts of the world, and it's pronounced exactly how you'd expect it to be.  There are also phrases like "in a jiff" or "jiffy".   In my opinion, it feels weird to pronounce "GIF" as "jif" because of that. That pronunciation already exists, whereas "gif" is brand new.  Obviously, there are countless words that are pronounced the same with different spellings, but I feel like nobody ever talks about "Jif" in any of these discussions.

I prefer g'if
Just because there's a most common way to pronounce a word doesn't mean that you have to use it.  A lot of words are pronounced in a variety of ways, and most of the time we don't even notice (notably because of allophones, but also for other reasons such as context or focalization effects). Some words are pronounced in different ways depending on your region, your age, your profession etc.  And anyway, the fact that both pronounciations are acceptable in English (even with a 70% dominance of one) probably means that both are good. What's interesting is that it's mostly people working with computers who are very opinoned about things like "gif". I believe it tells us something about how the "computer jargon" works. It's not really unlike how linguists used to be like when they were still called grammarians.

In spanish it's pronounced "gif" almost universally. Weird thing is: when a G is followed to an I in spanish the G becomes an "hispanic J" (like a very very hard H). Following spanish rules the word "gif" should be pronounced as "jif (esp)/Hif (eng)", but no one has done so. We all say "gif" (no "d3if" either).

Here in Spain I think nobody says GIF as in gin. As far as I can remember, I've always heard GIF as in give, and that is the way it should be pronounced.  Oddly enough, and since it's an acronym and not "a real word", if it were to be pronounced by Spanish standards it would be completely different from those two options, as a "g" immediatly before an "i" (or an "e") is pronounced like an English "h", so kind of "hif". So we pronounce it correctly by not playing by our own rules.

I think the way people pronounce gif is also majorly dependent on their native language. As a native Norwegian speaker, at no point did it occur to me to refer to it as 'jif' rather than 'gif' simply because G is only tied to the hard g sound in Norwegian, whereas the j in jif doesn't exist in the language at all. I think the same applies to a lot of other languages.

Not all of linguistics works the way Tom desribes. There are codified languages (slovak being one of them) for which a central institution decides what is correct and what is not. When the folk-language changes they sometimes decide to incorporate the changes into the language proper.

Spanish is typically not descriptive (an institution, the Real Academia Espa√±ola - Royal Spanish Academy, dictates what words are proper in Spanish, how they are pronounced, written, used, etc.) and it still allows some words to be pronounced/written in two or more ways at once. A classic example is the word for bat (the animal) which can be spelled (and pronounced) both as Murci√©lago or Murci√©galo

Well, in Romania we read it GIF (with a J) so..Jif. Because as a general rule, in Romanian language we write "GI"  and pronounce as in "Gin"  and  we write "GHI"  pronounce as in "Gift". It is one of those things which is drilled into our brains in primary school.  So to be read as GIF (as in Gift) for us it would have to be written as GHIF. Which is not. So we don't. The same rule applies with "GE" and "GHE".
All the jokes aside, I think it should be pronouced GIF. (like GIVE) Because there's also a .JIF format... Doesn't make sense we have 2 formats with same pronouciation.

I favour […ü…™f]. A non-attentive listener is likely to hear it as their preference regardless of what their preference is due to […ü] having something of an intermediate sound and not being phonemic in any dialect of English (we see this in for example people who speak dialects without the pin pen merger listening to speakers who do have the merger; their brains just pick whichever sound it thinks it should be closer to rather than actually hearing the intermediate sound). And typographically it's rotationally symmetric and that's just neat.    Credit to Randall Monroe of xkcd for coming up with this solution.

In Finnish this is easy. We pronounce 99,9 % of the words as they are written. Giuseppe is really pronounced like that.  But many times we would say that /kif/, because we have traditionally only non-voiced stops /k t p/ and voiced ones /b d g/ exist in loan words like "banaani", "dingo" and "greippi".  So I think that I say /gif/, but probably many times I say /kif/. This is the first lesson of Rally English.

Its GIF with a G because we pronounce acronyms letter by letter together, as it is not a word, this is true for every single acronym, we seperate the individual letter sounds then form it into a word, we take G, I and F and mash them together for GIF when said its said with a G sound as it is not a J, you can't apply the rules for how to said words to things which are not words and follow their own rules...

Here is the end of the debate on ALL WORDS. The creator of a word literally has no say in its pronunciation. Really none. Reality is words are not made by one person, but a collection of people who agree to call something a set of letters and sounds. So when the majority say it is Gif as in Gift. Then that is how it is pronounced. Period. Because language has 1 true rule and 1 true rule only. Majority rules.
